ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned many new systems of teaching Russian that I had never heard of before and were not used when I was taught.

More than anything I learned how to apply various pedagogical methods and tactics to fit varying circumstances in a classroom. I learned that having and understanding of linguistics is important for practical application, especially for first year students, additionally, I feel that we touched on significant aspects of the diversity of student language acquisition. I also gained valuable knowledge in the presentation of various language principles and where to find appropriate reference material.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought that the class was overall effective. It was productive to conduct class in Russian and to move through a variety of language principles, particularly in the target language. The presentations were helpful and helped to give me an idea of how I will present material in my own classroom. I additionally thought we could have touched a bit more on the macro processes, such as formulating lesson plans and classroom management.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class to other students in the PhD program, as it is absolutely necessary before stepping into the classroom.
